standard_metadata.standard_description: Add and subtract mixed numbers with like denominators, e.g., by replacing each mixed number with an equivalent fraction, and/or by using properties of operations and the relationship between addition and subtraction.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Add and subtract mixed numbers word problems (like denominators)

question.content: A zookeeper records how many scoops of peanuts she feeds the elephants for several days.   Day | Scoops :- | :-: Monday| $20\dfrac{7}{8}$ Tuesday| $21$ Wednesday| $19\dfrac58$  **How many more scoops of peanuts did the zookeeper feed the elephants on Tuesday than on Wednesday?**   scoops

hints.content: We need to subtract to find out how many more scoops of peanuts the zookeeper fed the elephants on Tuesday than on Wednesday.

We can line up the mixed numbers by their whole number parts and fractional parts, and then look at the fractions first:  $\begin{align} &\blueD{21} &\blueD\\\\ -&\maroonD{19}&\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{8}}\\ \hline{}\end{align}$  We can't subtract the $\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{8}}$, because we don't have any eighths to subtract from.

$\blueD{21}$ can be regrouped so that it also has a fractional part and we can subtract $\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{8}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueD{21} &= \blueD{20+  1} \\ \\ &= \blueD{20 +  \dfrac{8}{8}} \\ \\ &= \blueD{20 \dfrac{8}{8}}  \end{align}$
Now subtract the fractions.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{20} &\blueD{\dfrac88}\\\\ -&\maroonD{19}&\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{8}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\greenD{\dfrac{3}{8}} \end{align}$
Next, subtract the whole numbers.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{20} &\blueD{\dfrac88}\\\\ -&\maroonD{19}&\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{8}}\\ \hline{}\\ & \greenD1&\greenD{\dfrac{3}{8}} \end{align}$
The zookeeper fed the elephants $1\dfrac38$ more scoops of peanuts on Tuesday than on Wednesday.

question.content: After a rain storm, Lily measures the depth of several puddles in her backyard. She records her results in a table.   Puddle |Depth (inches) :- | :-: On the lawn| $\dfrac34$ On the sidewalk | $\dfrac24$ Under the swing | $1\dfrac14$  **How much deeper was the puddle under the swing than the puddle on the sidewalk?**   inches

hints.content: We need to subtract to find out how much deeper the puddle under the swing was.

We can line up the numbers by their whole number parts and fractional parts, and then look at the fractions first.   $\begin{align} &\blueD{1} &\blueD{\dfrac{1}{4}}\\\\ -&&\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{4}}\\ \hline{} \end{align}$  We can't subtract $\blueD{\dfrac{1}{4}} - \maroonD{\dfrac{2}{4}}$, because $\blueD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ is **less** than $\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{4}}$.

$\blueD{1\dfrac{1}{4}}$ can be regrouped so that the fractional part is **greater** than $\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{4}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueD{1\dfrac{1}{4}} &= \blueD{1+  \dfrac{1}{4}} \\ \\ &= \blueD{ \dfrac{4}{4} +  \dfrac{1}{4}} \\ \\ &= \blueD{\dfrac{5}{4}} \end{align}$
Now, subtract the fractions.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{} &\blueD{\dfrac{5}{4}}\\\\ -&\pink{}&\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{4}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\greenD{\dfrac{3}{4}} \end{align}$
The puddle under the swing was $\dfrac34$ inch deeper than the puddle on the sidewalk.

question.content: Maya measures the weights of several fruits at the grocery store. She records her results in a table.  The watermelon weighs $7\dfrac34$ pounds more than the pineapple.  **Record the weight of the watermelon in the table.**  Fruit |Weight (pounds) - | :-:  Watermelon|  Pineapple| $1\dfrac2{4}$ Bag of apples| $5$ Banana|$\dfrac14$

hints.content: We need to add to find the weight of the watermelon.

We can line up the mixed numbers by their whole number parts and fractional parts, and then add the fractions first:  $\begin{align} &\blueD{7} &\blueD{\dfrac{3}{4}}\\\\ +&\maroonD{1}&\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{4}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\greenD{\dfrac{5}{4}} \end{align}$

Because $\greenD{\dfrac{5}{4}}$ is greater than $1$, it must be converted into a mixed number.  $\begin{align} \greenD{\dfrac{5}{4}} &= \greenD{\dfrac{4}{4} +  \dfrac{1}{4}} \\ \\ &= \greenD{1  \dfrac{1}{4}}  \end{align}$  Then, we put the $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{4}}$ under the fractions and the $\greenD{1}$ with the other whole numbers.  $\begin{align} &\greenD{1} \\ &\blueD{7} &\blueD{\dfrac{3}{4}}\\\\ +&\maroonD{1}&\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{4}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\greenD{\dfrac{1}{4}} \end{align}$
Next, add the whole numbers:  $\begin{align} &\greenD{1} \\ &\blueD{7} &\blueD{\dfrac{3}{4}}\\\\ +&\maroonD{1}&\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{4}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\greenD{9}&\greenD{\dfrac{1}{4}} \end{align}$
The watermelon weighed $9\dfrac14$ pounds.

question.content: Alicia hikes to see a waterfall. She records the weight of the items she put in her backpack in a table.   Alicia's camera weighs $1\dfrac35\text{ kg}$ less than her lunch.  **Record the weight of Alicia's camera in the table.**  Item|Weight (kg) :- | :-: Water bottle| $1\dfrac2{5}$ Camera|  Lunch| $2\dfrac1{5}$

hints.content: Alicia's camera weighs less than her lunch. So, we need to subtract to find the weight of the camera.

We can line up the mixed numbers by their whole number parts and fractional parts, and then look at the fractions first:  $\begin{align} &\blueD{2} &\blueD{\dfrac{1}{5}}\\\\ -&\maroonD{1}&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}}\\ \hline{} \end{align}$  We can't subtract $\blueD{\dfrac{1}{5}} - \maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}}$, because $\blueD{\dfrac{1}{5}}$ is **less** than $\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}}$.

$\blueD{2\dfrac{1}{5}}$ can be regrouped so that the fractional part is **greater** than $\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueD{2\dfrac{1}{5}} &= \blueD{2+  \dfrac{1}{5}} \\ \\ &= \blueD{1 +  1 +  \dfrac{1}{5}} \\ \\ &= \blueD{1 +  \dfrac{5}{5} +  \dfrac{1}{5}} \\ \\ &= \blueD{1 \dfrac{6}{5}}  \end{align}$
Now, subtract the fractions.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{1} &\blueD{\dfrac{6}{5}}\\\\ -&\maroonD{1}&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\greenD{}&\greenD{\dfrac{3}{5}} \end{align}$
Next, subtract the whole numbers:   $\begin{align} &\blueD{1} &\blueD{\dfrac{6}{5}}\\\\ -&\maroonD{1}&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\greenD{0}&\greenD{\dfrac{3}{5}} \end{align}$
Alicia's camera weighs $\dfrac35\text{ kg}$.

question.content: One snowy day, Ona records the lengths of several different types of sleds that she found in her garage.   Type of sled |Length (feet) :- | :-: Saucer| $2\dfrac{2}{12}$ Inner tube| $2\dfrac{7}{12}$ Foam sled| $3\dfrac{4}{12}$  **What is the combined length of the saucer and the inner tube?**   feet

hints.content: We need to add to find the total length of the saucer and the inner tube.

We can line up the mixed numbers by their whole number parts and fractional parts, and then add the fractions first:  $\begin{align} &\blueD{2} &\blueD{\dfrac{2}{12}}\\\\ +&\maroonD2&\maroonD{\dfrac{7}{12}}\\ \hline{} &&\greenD{\dfrac{9}{12}} \end{align}$
Next, add the whole numbers:   $\begin{align} &\blueD{2} &\blueD{\dfrac{2}{12}}\\\\ +&\maroonD2&\maroonD{\dfrac{7}{12}}\\ \hline{} &\greenD4&\greenD{\dfrac{9}{12}} \end{align}$
The combined length of the saucer and inner tube is  $4\dfrac{9}{12}$ feet.  We could also write this as $4\dfrac34$.

question.content: Kyra and some friends go to a climbing gym. She records how high each person climbed.   Person|Height (m) :- | :-: Kyra| $5\dfrac{40}{100}$ Jake| $7\dfrac{10}{100}$ Minna| $4\dfrac{85}{100}$  **What is the total height climbed by Kyra and Jake?**   meters

hints.content: We need to add to find the total height climbed by Kyra and Jake.

We can line up the mixed numbers by their whole number parts and fractional parts, and then add the fractions first:  $\begin{align} &\blueD{5} &\blueD{\dfrac{40}{100}}\\\\ +&\maroonD7&\maroonD{\dfrac{10}{100}}\\ \hline{} &&\greenD{\dfrac{50}{100}} \end{align}$
Next, add the whole numbers:   $\begin{align} &\blueD{5} &\blueD{\dfrac{40}{100}}\\\\ +&\maroonD7&\maroonD{\dfrac{10}{100}}\\ \hline{} &\greenD{12}&\greenD{\dfrac{50}{100}} \end{align}$
Kyra and Jake climbed a total of $12\dfrac{50}{100}$ meters.  We could also write this as $12\dfrac12$ meters.

question.content: Amy collected a few insects in her backyard. She recorded their lengths in a table.   Insect|Length (cm) :- | :-: Worm| $8\dfrac8{10}$ Caterpillar | $4\dfrac2{10}$ Ant | $\dfrac5{10}$  **How much longer is the worm than the ant?**   centimeters

hints.content: We need to subtract to find out how much longer the worm is than the ant.

We can line up the mixed numbers by their whole number parts and fractional parts, and then subtract the fractions first:  $\begin{align} &\blueD{8} &\blueD{\dfrac{8}{10}}\\\\ -&&\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{10}}\\ \hline{} &&\greenD{\dfrac{3}{10}} \end{align}$
Next, subtract the whole numbers:   $\begin{align} &\blueD{8} &\blueD{\dfrac{8}{10}}\\\\ -&\maroonD0&\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{10}}\\ \hline{} &\greenD8&\greenD{\dfrac{3}{10}} \end{align}$
The worm is  $8\dfrac3{10}$ centimeters longer than the ant.

question.content: Evan and two friends go to a farm to pick strawberries. Evan records the number of baskets of strawberries that each person picks in a table.  Evan forgot to record how many strawberries he picked, but he knows that it was the same amount as Jerry and Ann combined.  **Record the number of baskets of strawberries that Evan picked in the table.**  Person| Number of baskets :- | :-: Evan|  Jerry |$2\dfrac13$ Ann| $3\dfrac1{3}$

hints.content: Evan picked as many strawberries as Jerry and Ann combined. So, we need to add to find out how many strawberries Evan picked.

We can line up the mixed numbers by their whole number parts and fractional parts, and then add the fractions first:  $\begin{align} &\blueD{2} &\blueD{\dfrac{1}{3}}\\\\ +&\maroonD{3}&\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}}\\ \hline{} &&\greenD{\dfrac{2}{3}} \end{align}$
Next, add the whole numbers:  $\begin{align} &\blueD{2} &\blueD{\dfrac{1}{3}}\\\\ +&\maroonD{3}&\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{3}}\\ \hline{} &\greenD5&\greenD{\dfrac{2}{3}} \end{align}$
Evan picked $5\dfrac23$ baskets of strawberries.

question.content: Mia starts with a piece of paper that is $6\text{ cm}$ long. She folds the paper into a dragon that is  $2\dfrac12\text{ cm}$ long.  **How much longer was the original paper than the dragon?**   centimeters

hints.content: We need to subtract to find out how much longer the paper was than the dragon.

We can line up the mixed numbers by their whole number parts and fractional parts, and then look at the fractions first:  $\begin{align} &\blueD{6} &\blueD\\\\ -&\maroonD{2}&\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}\\ \hline{} \end{align}$  We can't subtract the $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$, because we don't have any halves to subtract from.

$\blueD{6}$ can be regrouped so that it also has a fractional part and we can subtract $\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueD{6} &= \blueD{5+  1} \\ \\ &= \blueD{5 +  \dfrac{2}{2}} \\ \\ &= \blueD{5 \dfrac{2}{2}}  \end{align}$
Now, subtract the fractions.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{5} &\blueD{\dfrac{2}{2}}\\\\ -&\maroonD{2}&\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\greenD{}&\greenD{\dfrac{1}{2}} \end{align}$
Next, subtract the whole numbers:  $\begin{align} &\blueD{5} &\blueD{\dfrac{2}{2}}\\\\ -&\maroonD{2}&\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{2}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\greenD{3}&\greenD{\dfrac{1}{2}} \end{align}$
The piece of paper was $3\dfrac12$ centimeters longer than the dragon.

question.content: Kayden walks $\dfrac{4}{5}$  kilometer to a friend's house. Then he and his friend walk $1\dfrac3{5}$ kilometers more to go fishing at their favorite pond.  **How far did Kayden walk all together?**   kilometers

hints.content: We need to add the distance Kayden walked to his friend's house and the distance they walked to the pond to find out how far Kayden walked all together.

We can line up the mixed numbers by their whole number parts and fractional parts, and then add the fractions first.   $\begin{align} &\blueD{} &\blueD{\dfrac{4}{5}}\\\\ +&\maroonD{1}&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\greenD{\dfrac{7}{5}} \end{align}$

Because $\greenD{\dfrac{7}{5}}$ is greater than $1$, it must be converted into a mixed number.  $\begin{align} \greenD{\dfrac{7}{5}} &= \greenD{\dfrac{5}{5} +  \dfrac{2}{5}} \\ \\ &= \greenD{1  \dfrac{2}{5}}  \end{align}$  Then, we put the $\greenD{\dfrac{2}{5}}$ under the fractions and the $\greenD{1}$ with the other whole numbers.  $\begin{align} &\greenD{1} \\ &\blueD{} &\blueD{\dfrac{4}{5}}\\\\ +&\maroonD{1}&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\greenD{\dfrac{2}{5}} \end{align}$
Next, add the whole numbers.  $\begin{align} &\greenD{1} \\ &\blueD{} &\blueD{\dfrac{4}{5}}\\\\ +&\maroonD{1}&\maroonD{\dfrac{3}{5}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\greenD2&\greenD{\dfrac{2}{5}} \end{align}$
Kayden walked $2\dfrac25$ kilometers all together.

question.content: Frank's dog Dynamite spent $3\dfrac9{12}$ minutes playing in the mud. Later, Frank spent $8\dfrac5{12}$ minutes giving Dynamite a bath.  **How much longer did Dynamite spend getting a bath than playing in the mud?**   minutes

hints.content: We need to subtract to find out how much longer Dynamite spent getting a bath than playing in the mud.

We can line up the mixed numbers by their whole number parts and fractional parts, and then look at the fractions first:  $\begin{align} &\blueD{8} &\blueD{\dfrac5{12}}\\\\ -&\maroonD{3}&\maroonD{\dfrac{9}{12}}\\ \hline{} \end{align}$  We can't subtract $\blueD{\dfrac{5}{12}} - \maroonD{\dfrac{9}{12}}$, because $\blueD{\dfrac{5}{12}}$ is **less** than $\maroonD{\dfrac{9}{12}}$.

$\blueD{8\dfrac{5}{12}}$ can be regrouped so that the fractional part is **greater** than $\maroonD{\dfrac{9}{12}}$.  $\begin{align} \blueD{8\dfrac{5}{12}} &= \blueD{8+  \dfrac{5}{12}} \\ \\ &= \blueD{7 +  1 +  \dfrac{5}{12}} \\ \\ &= \blueD{7 +  \dfrac{12}{12} +  \dfrac{5}{12}} \\ \\ &= \blueD{7 \dfrac{17}{12}}  \end{align}$
Now, subtract the fractions.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{7} &\blueD{\dfrac{17}{12}}\\\\ -&\maroonD{3}&\maroonD{\dfrac{9}{12}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\greenD{}&\greenD{\dfrac{8}{12}} \end{align}$
Next, subtract the whole numbers:  $\begin{align} &\blueD{7} &\blueD{\dfrac{17}{12}}\\\\ -&\maroonD{3}&\maroonD{\dfrac{9}{12}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\greenD{4}&\greenD{\dfrac{8}{12}} \end{align}$
Dynamite spent $4\dfrac8{12}$ minutes longer getting a bath than playing in the mud.  We can also write this as $4\dfrac23$ minutes.

question.content: Ava's birthday cake is $11\dfrac{7}{10}\text{ cm}$ tall. Her candles stick up from the cake an additional  $5\dfrac4{10}\text{ cm}$.  **What is the total height of the cake and candles?**   centimeters

hints.content: We need to add to find the total height of the cake and candles.

We can line up the mixed numbers by their whole number parts and fractional parts, and then add the fractions first.   $\begin{align} &\blueD{11} &\blueD{\dfrac{7}{10}}\\\\ +&\maroonD{5}&\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{10}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\greenD{\dfrac{11}{10}} \end{align}$

Because $\greenD{\dfrac{11}{10}}$ is greater than $1$, it must be converted into a mixed number.  $\begin{align} \greenD{\dfrac{11}{10}} &= \greenD{\dfrac{10}{10} +  \dfrac{1}{10}} \\ \\ &= \greenD{1  \dfrac{1}{10}}  \end{align}$  Then, we put the $\greenD{\dfrac{1}{10}}$ under the fractions and the $\greenD{1}$ with the other whole numbers.  $\begin{align} &\greenD{1} \\ &\blueD{11} &\blueD{\dfrac{7}{10}}\\\\ +&\maroonD{5}&\pink{\dfrac{4}{10}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\greenD{\dfrac{1}{10}} \end{align}$
Next, add the whole numbers.  $\begin{align} &\greenD{1} \\ &\blueD{11} &\blueD{\dfrac{7}{10}}\\\\ +&\maroonD{5}&\maroonD{\dfrac{4}{10}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\greenD{17}&\greenD{\dfrac{1}{10}} \end{align}$
The total height of the cake and candles is  $17\dfrac1{10}$ centimeters.

question.content: Kate started with a piece of bubblegum that was $\dfrac58\text{ in}$ wide. She later blew a bubble that was $2\dfrac78\text{ in}$ wide.  **How much wider was Kate's bubble than the original piece of bubblegum?**   inches

hints.content: We need to subtract to find out how much larger the bubble was than the piece of gum.

We can line up the mixed numbers by their whole number parts and fractional parts, and then subtract the fractions first:  $\begin{align} &\blueD{2} &\blueD{\dfrac{7}{8}}\\\\ -&\maroonD{}&\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{8}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\greenD{\dfrac{2}{8}} \end{align}$
Next, subtract the whole numbers:  $\begin{align} &\blueD{2} &\blueD{\dfrac{7}{8}}\\\\ -&\maroonD{0}&\maroonD{\dfrac{5}{8}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\greenD{2}&\greenD{\dfrac{2}{8}} \end{align}$
Kate's bubble was $2\dfrac28$ inches larger than the original piece of gum.  We can also write this as $2\dfrac14$ inches.

question.content: Archer made a tunnel for his hamster out of two cardboard tubes. One tube was $8\dfrac{5}{8}\text{ in}$ long. The other tube was $7\dfrac6{8}\text{ in}$ long.  **What is the total length of the tunnel?**   inches

hints.content: We need to add to find the length of both tubes together.

We can line up the mixed numbers by their whole number parts and fractional parts, and then add the fractions first.   $\begin{align} &\blueD{8} &\blueD{\dfrac{5}{8}}\\\\ +&\maroonD{7}&\maroonD{\dfrac{6}{8}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\greenD{\dfrac{11}{8}} \end{align}$

Because $\greenD{\dfrac{11}{8}}$ is greater than $1$, it must be converted into a mixed number.  $\begin{align} \greenD{\dfrac{11}{8}} &= \greenD{\dfrac{8}{8} +  \dfrac{3}{8}} \\ \\ &= \greenD{1  \dfrac{3}{8}}  \end{align}$  Then, we put the $\greenD{\dfrac{3}{8}}$ under the fractions and the $\greenD{1}$ with the other whole numbers.  $\begin{align} &\greenD{1} \\ &\blueD{8} &\blueD{\dfrac{5}{8}}\\\\ +&\maroonD{7}&\maroonD{\dfrac{6}{8}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\greenD{\dfrac{3}{8}} \end{align}$
Next, add the whole numbers.  $\begin{align} &\greenD{1} \\ &\blueD{8} &\blueD{\dfrac{5}{8}}\\\\ +&\maroonD{7}&\maroonD{\dfrac{6}{8}}\\ \hline{} &\greenD{16}&\greenD{\dfrac{3}{8}} \end{align}$
The total length of the tunnel is $16\dfrac38$ inches.

question.content: Kay sees a gorilla handprint at the zoo that is $16\dfrac{5}{10}\text{ cm}$ wide. Her own hand is $5\dfrac1{10}\text{ cm}$ wide.  **How much wider is the gorilla hand than Kay's hand?**   centimeters

hints.content: We need to subtract to find out how much wider the gorilla hand is than Kay's hand.

We can line up the mixed numbers by their whole number parts and fractional parts, and then subtract  the fractions first:  $\begin{align} &\blueD{16} &\blueD{\dfrac5{10}}\\\\ -&\maroonD{5}&\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{10}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\greenD{}&\greenD{\dfrac{4}{10}} \end{align}$
Next, subtract the whole numbers:  $\begin{align} &\blueD{16} &\blueD{\dfrac{5}{10}}\\\\ -&\maroonD{5}&\maroonD{\dfrac{1}{10}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\greenD{11}&\greenD{\dfrac{4}{10}} \end{align}$
The gorilla's hand is $11\dfrac4{10}$ cm wider than Kay's hand.  We can also write this as $11\dfrac25$.

question.content: The Bing family spent $1\dfrac{1}{4}$ hours driving to the beach. Then they spent $3\dfrac2{4}$ hours playing in the sand and water.  **How long did the Bing family spend all together driving to and playing at the beach ?**   hours

hints.content: We need to add to find the total amount of time the Bing family spent driving to and playing at the beach.

We can line up the mixed numbers by their whole number parts and fractional parts, and then add the fractions first.   $\begin{align} &\blueD{1} &\blueD{\dfrac{1}{4}}\\\\ +&\maroonD{3}&\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{4}}\\ \hline{}\\ &&\greenD{\dfrac{3}{4}} \end{align}$
Next, add the whole numbers.  $\begin{align} &\blueD{1} &\blueD{\dfrac{1}{4}}\\\\ +&\maroonD{3}&\maroonD{\dfrac{2}{4}}\\ \hline{}\\ &\greenD4&\greenD{\dfrac{3}{4}} \end{align}$
The Bing family spent a total of $4\dfrac34$ hours driving to and playing at the beach.
